text: Bottle at Nagano Sake Village into a stem glass. Thanks TimE for the rec! Hazy dark brown with tan head. Aromas of caramel, dark fruit, light chocolate. Tastes of caramel, dark fruit, sweet malt. Medium body with a dry finish. Nicely done.
Bottle - Wheat, smoke and toasted malts. Jet brown with a tiny brown head. Smoke, raisin and dark fruit. Sweet but nice.

33 cl bottle @ home, from IP trade with TimE - thanks! Label says 6% btw. Very dark brown color. Short beige head with good retention. Aromas: some roasted malts, drop/licorice, fruit confit, slightly sour, just a hint of banana. Retronasal theres a bit of the sourness of the wheat. Flavor is light to moderate sweet, roasted malt. Body is rather full. Flavor lingers. Maybe it got too old, but its not very true to the style. Pleasant enough though.
Cherry aroma, red fruit, roasted malt. Plum juice, biscuit, sour finish. Nice creamy and fruity Dunkel.
On tap at Ibaraki Bakuon 2013. A cola pour with a beige head. A good mix of weizen & Dunkel with the spiciness & hint of caramel-quite good.
Draught. Aroma of sweet fruits, raisins, dark chocolate. Not fantastic to look at, but the flavours and balance of this were sensational. Rich and creamy. Fantastic depth. Loved it.
Bottle at Shinshu Sake Mura. Dark brown colour, big golden creamy head. Aroma bubblegum, banana, soy sauce. Taste is roasty, wheaty, bit of creaminess. Quite different. Pretty nice.
Not too weizen like - some raisin, a bit of banana, bready and soft grassy/floral hops. Different but a bit non descript.
Bottle at Shinshu Osake Mura. Black colour with a small beige head. Faint aroma of vinegar, banana. Flavour of banana, licorice.

Bottle. Pours muddy brown with a creamy beige head. The aroma is spot on. A pleasant spicyness with underlying caramel, chocolate, wheat and banana. At no point is the spice to intense. Its well crafted and the nuances really compliment the overall balance. I really enjoyed this. (RateBeer Sydney Xmas Gathering 2009 - cheers TimE!)

I get the feeling the bottled version doesnt capture the magic of the draught. The bottle we had seemed solid but was let down by an over-fizzy palate - perhaps because it was straight off a plane from Japan. Ive given my palate rating the benefit of the doubt on that basis. Certainly a good-looking dunkel with the sort of head retention youd expect. Sweet and wheaty under the nose but a little indistinct. As sweet as the rest of the range sampled, with plenty of molasses, toffee and mashed bananas before a sour finish. (Ratebeer Sydney Xmas gathering under the harbour bridge, 2009. Beer courtesy of TimE - thanks buddy.)

Very dark in color with little head.  Rich malts, but lacking much wheat aroma or flavor.  Some dark fruits, and light banana.  Oily, smooth body,  A good brew, but would like a little more weizen in this dunkel.

Draught at Towers, Tokyo.  Cloudy nut brown. Toasty with licorice and banana . Dry, even crisp thoug hsparkling, with light-medium body. Wonderful balance between licorice and banana, lovely depth in flavour and a welcome twist of the style. The worlds best dunkelweizen?

UPDATED: MAR 22, 2012 Bottle. Dark, rich malts, but with less wheat flavor than expected. Much more like a Munich dunkel, but with a bit of wheat flavor added. Rich, complex malts, though. And decently balanced. Tasty and different.

My Bottom Line:
Plump earthiness and plum fruitiness slide along this Dunkelweizens juicy banana esters. This rich and unique recipe of Minamishinsyus might be their finest libation.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A frothy head of foam protects the murky dark brown.
-Clovey phenols are well integrated and, fitting with the sweet earthiness, add complexity.
-Dark chocolate is even perceived alongside the finishing earthiness and roastiness.
-This is not your typical Dunkelweizen with its focus on wheat and caramel malts, but rather a bona fide Dunkel (or black lager) which happens to use a weizen yeast. A nice twist to say the least!

On tap at the brewery restaurant.

Dark brown color, caramel, cloves, bananas, milk chocolate earthy nose. The mouth reminded me of a Banana Sunday from Dairy Queen, but not as sweet. Drinking this beert gave me the same happy feeling I had when I had a Sundae when I was a kid. Perhaps they should market this as a semi-sweet liquid Banana Sunday. I would go for it.
